-----Original Message-----
From: David Roussel [mailto:dir@...]
Sent: Wednesday, August 15, 2001 9:42 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Re: writing a test case for a function which
returns void


Here's a simple example.

public class Accumulator {
	int acc;

	public int getValue() {
		return acc;
	}

	public void add( int inc )
		acc += inc;
	}
}

public class TestAccumulator {
 	...

	testAdd() {
		Accumulator a = new Accumulator();
		assertEquals( 0, a.getValue() );
		a.add( 5 );
		assertEquals( 5, a.getValue() );
		a.add( 50 );
		assertEquals( 55, a.getValue() );
	}
}

-----Original Message-----
From: Tariq Qazi [mailto:tariq.qazi@...]
Sent: 15 August 2001 14:35
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] Re: writing a test case for a function which

Yes, you can assert that is has changed the state of the object is was
invoked on.
